title: What is an XSS attack?
content: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is when attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Explain the potential risks and examples.
sampleAnswers: XSS is when an attacker injects scripts into a page to steal cookies, hijack sessions, or manipulate the DOM. Examples: stored XSS in comments, reflected XSS in search forms, DOM-based XSS via URL parameters.

title: Which of the following are types of XSS attacks?
content: Select all types of XSS attacks.
explanation: DOM-based, Reflected, and Stored are the three main XSS types. SQL Injection is a server-side attack.

title: True or False: CSRF attacks rely on user authentication.
content: Evaluate whether this statement is true or false.

options.explanation: CSRF exploits the fact that the user is already authenticated.

title: What is clickjacking?
content: Clickjacking is a type of attack where a user is tricked into clicking elements hidden under legitimate UI elements. Explain how it works and prevention strategies.
sampleAnswers: Clickjacking tricks users into clicking hidden elements using overlays or iframes. Prevention: X-Frame-Options header, CSP frame-ancestors, avoid transparent overlays.

title: Which HTTP header helps prevent clickjacking?
content: Select the correct header used to prevent clickjacking attacks.
explanation: X-Frame-Options and CSP frame-ancestors prevent malicious iframe embedding.

title: True or False: MITM attacks only affect unsecured HTTP connections.
content: Evaluate whether this statement is true or false.

options.explanation: MITM can also target HTTPS via certificate spoofing or rogue networks.
Even HTTPS can be vulnerable if certificates are compromised.

title: How do HttpOnly and Secure cookies improve security?
content: Explain how the HttpOnly and Secure flags help prevent attacks.
sampleAnswers: HttpOnly prevents JavaScript from reading cookies (protects against XSS). Secure ensures cookies are only sent over HTTPS.

title: Which of these is a recommended prevention for XSS in React?
explanation: Avoid unsafe HTML, sanitize inputs, and validate server-side to prevent XSS.

title: True or False: CSP (Content Security Policy) can help mitigate XSS.
content: Evaluate whether this statement is true or false.

options.explanation: CSP restricts allowed script sources, mitigating XSS.
